oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Interview - Clive Davis - 2017-03-14 / Interview with and performance by John Prine - 2017-03-14
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Interview with Clive Davis as the featured speaker for Leadership Music Nashville from the CMA Theater at the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum on March 14, 2017. Interview conducted by Julie Swindler. Includes audio from video presentation. Recording also includes Leadership Music interview with John Prine, Jody Wheelman and Fiona Prine conducted by Peter Cooper. Includes questions from the audience and performances by John Prine and Joel Mossier.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Clive Davis; John Prine; Jody Whalen; Fiona Prine; Jonell Mosser;
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: Recording begins in progress / (00:00) Davis talks about growing up and his early work at a law firm and then taking a job as legal counsel for Columbia Records / (02:14) Davis talks about how he became President of Columbia Records and talks about Gouda Libbers' influence / (05:13) Davis talks about his initial challenges as Columbia Records President and making first deal with producer Lou Adler and Scott McKenzie's San Francisco (Be Sure To Wear Flowers In Your Hair / (07:26) Attending the Monterey Pop Festival in 1967 and it being a life changing event for him / (08:37) Talks about the festival being a revolution and about seeing Janis Joplin there and signing her and the Electric Flag / (10:31) Talks about building a track record by signing artists, building a pop music team at Columbia and signing Blood, Sweat and Tears among others / (12:10) Davis talks about the development of his listening skills and business acumen /

(13:41) Working with Gamble and Huff and getting outside of the rock genre / (14:28) Davis talks about hit songs and trying to make hit recordings / (14:47) Talks about two years of a fraud scandal, being a sacrificial lamb and learning to overcome / (16:29) Starting Aristae Records and his hunger to be a major player again / (17:32) Branching out musically and focusing more on the repertoire side of the business / (18:21) Presenting the song Mandy to Barry Manila and it being the first number one hit for Aristae Records / (19:00) Building a track record and backlog of what he considered to be hit songs / (20:17) Signing Dianne Airsick and reviving her career / (21:29) Working with Martha Franklin and continuing the growth of Aristae Records / (23:10) Davis tells where the name Aristae came from and what it was like starting over again / (25:24) Davis talks about Whitney Houston and the song The Greatest Love Of All /
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Davis, Clive; Prine, John; Whalen, Jody; Prine, Fiona; Mosser, Jonell; Country Music Hall of Fame & Museum (Nashville, Tenn.);
